docs.lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett disclosed on Tuesday that he had prostate cancer, a development that would probably heighten the questions over his successor as the chief executive of his conglomerate, Berkshire Hathaway. Yet Mr. Buffett, who will turn 82 this summer, also made clear that he would continue to run the company, writing to shareholders that the disease was in Stage 1 and that he had been told by doctors that it was ''not remotely life-threatening or even debilitating in any meaningful way.''

headline.main: Revealing Prostate Cancer, Buffett Plays Down Effect

docs.abstract: Warren E Buffett discloses that he has prostate cancer, heightening questions over his successor as the chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway; says he continue to run the company, reassuring shareholders that the disease is in the early stages and will not affect his performance. Photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors with a financial interest in a laboratory are more likely to send prostate samples, according to a new study, but the rate of cancer detection is no higher.

headline.seo: Urologist’s Stake in Laboratory Affects Number of Prostate Biopsies
headline.main: Patterns: Doctor’s Stake in Lab Affects Biopsy Rate
headline.print_headline: Patterns: Doctor’s Stake in Lab Affects Biopsy Rate

docs.abstract: Dr Jean M Mitchell study in journal Health Affairs finds that urologists with a financial interest in a laboratory send more prostate biopsies for analysis and have a lower rate of cancer detection than those who use independent labs.
docs.snippet: Doctors with a financial interest in a laboratory are more likely to send prostate samples, according to a new study, but the rate of cancer detection is no higher.

docs.lead_paragraph: Until we figure out the true costs of delivering health care to patients, we can’t make the system more efficient.

headline.seo: Why Medical Bills Are a Mystery
headline.main: Why Medical Bills Are a Mystery
headline.print_headline: Why Medical Bills Are a Mystery

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Profs Robert S Kaplan and Michael E Porter, prompted by the realization that rising health care costs are busting budgets of the federal, state and local governments, offers suggestions for consolidating certain services to improve utilization and reduce some existing capacity; contends such changes will provide a path to combating increasing costs.
docs.snippet: Until we figure out the true costs of delivering health care to patients, we can’t make the system more efficient.

byline.original: By ROBERT S. KAPLAN and MICHAEL E. PORTER

docs.lead_paragraph: Much of the Earth’s population growth is in sub-Saharan African nations like Nigeria, where trends that have lowered birthrates elsewhere have not yet caught on.

headline.seo: In Nigeria, a Preview of an Overcrowded Planet
headline.main: Nigeria Tested by Rapid Rise in Population
headline.print_headline: Nigeria’s Population Is Soaring In Preview of a Global Problem

docs.abstract: Nigeria's booming population, which may exceed 300 million people in a quarter-century, is emblematic of a wider population problem across sub-Saharan Africa; trends that have reduced fertility rates elsewhere in the developing world have not yet caught on, and population has quickly outstripped economic expansion; Nigeria has now become a crucial test case for government efforts to reduce the birthrate, including free contraceptives.
docs.snippet: Much of the Earth’s population growth is in sub-Saharan African nations like Nigeria, where trends that have lowered birthrates elsewhere have not yet caught on.
